pros: There is a strong sense of community among administrative staff, and salaries/raises/benefits are very competitive compared to other colleges I've worked for. I have felt supported both professionally and personally while working here. It's been evident to me that Hamilton cares about its employees and strives to be a place people love to work. Leadership periodically solicits feedback on employee satisfaction, and I appreciate that commitment and transparency.
cons: None in my first year

pros: Hamilton has a strong feel of community. I've worked at other places and the sense I get from everyone here is that they want to be here. It' s a very welcoming and inclusive space. I truly love working here and look forward to growing here!
cons: When I first started, it was harder to build connections (albeit there were still covid restirctions in place).

pros: Hamilton is a great place to work for many reasons. Great benefits and people, plus the students are amazing. Awesome community.
cons: Salaries could be better to be competitive with local schools.

pros: Very lax environment to work in
cons: No stable hours and you have to give tours in the snow

pros: Great people in this college
cons: A little bit far from major cities

pros: You can always find a job that works with your schedule, helps you professionally, or exposes you to a whole new side of Hamilton!
cons: You will never get a pay raise, no matter what you do. The school will spend that money (and then some) on lawyers to make sure you don’t unionize.

pros: The Office of Admission is full of lovely people who are very easy to work with. The senior management is not always the best, but everyone else in the office is friendly and willing to help.
cons: Low pay, lots of work

Experience for future job applications

Students show you no respect at a liberal arts college.
You sacrifice enjoying college life

pros: Good learning environment, positive experience

review_title: A great student affairs environment to work in - if you don't mind the cold weather...
pros: As highly experienced staff and trained professionals I always knew that my supervisors had earned their positions in this field.  Most had gone to Hamilton as undergrads while others had over 10 years of experience at this institution.  They know what they are talking about.  Listen to them.
cons: Because so many of the staff were also undergraduates there at one point there is definitely a sense of institutional "incest" when it comes to institutional policies - with outside viewpoints often taking a backseat.  Be mindful of this when discussing university traditions.  Also winter here is a nine month season.  Be prepared for that.

review_title: Excellent people. Happy, caring, and willing to help
pros: The people are usually great. Will find very few who are unhappy to be there. As a lab consultant, there are many opportunities to be promoted!
cons: As a student, the pay is pretty poor and there are no opportunities to get benefits or increase compensation aside from working more. You can also end up with some crappy hours.

pros: The Hamilton College French Department offered much flexibility to teaching assistants in formatting their teaching sessions and allowed assistants to be creative in how they presented materials to students.
cons: Teaching assistants were sometimes left with little direction for conducting lessons. Students sometimes arrived at the teaching session unaware of what topics would be covered that week or how to prepare for drills.

review_title: Working with the Alumni Relations Department
pros: It was a great place to work, and really gave me a good grounding for how to work in an office environment. Everybody worked well together, good communication both within the office and to alumni committees and volunteers.
cons: Database software that they rely on for information is old and doesn't work properly, necessitating going through by hand to ensure information is sent to the correct people.

pros: There are lots of different jobs on campus, just be willing to try different things. Most people just complain that there are not enough jobs, but there is ALWAYS work to be had.
cons: Minimum wage is the standard all across the board. It's hard to make more than that. Some jobs get paid to do MINDLESS work and skilled student worker jobs get paid the same.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Mathematics in Clinton, NY
pros: Superb students. Magnificent physical plant. Skilled teachers focused on teaching. Need-blind admission covering full demonstrated need - serious about being a school of opportunity. Committed and generous trustees. Intimate and engaged community.
cons: Winters tend to be long. Support systems for multicultural and international students are developing and not fully in place.

review_title: Great way to get work experience
pros: We all know employers want work experience but you can't get work experience without a job -- this is the famous paradox. Hamilton will hire pretty much any student as a student worker. This is the best way to get job experience before graduation.
cons: The pay is basically minimum wage.

job_title: QSR Center Tutor in Clinton, NY
pros: I loved going to this school and I loved being able to work there as well.  I worked in the QSR center as a math tutor.
cons: Not much pay, minimum wage.  No room for development but thats to be expected since it's a school.

review_title: Working for Hamilton College is a good gig.
pros: Great atmosphere and plenty of resources.  The grounds are very well kept, the work schedule is flexible when necessary, and the benefits are generous.
cons: The level of community is not as strong as it could be.

pros: Great people Never boring, each call could bring a different situation.Officers were well trained and could handle most situations.Calls to other departments were handled in a timely manner.
cons: rules would change on a daily basis
